description: A simple, nutritious, and quick-to-prepare wild green, sautéed with basic aromatics. Bbuga has a mild, slightly earthy flavor and a tender texture when cooked, similar to spinach but often found growing wild.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Bbuga is a classic example of a foraged wild green that has sustained rural communities for generations. It often grows as a weed in farmland and gardens, and its harvesting is a common practice, especially during the rainy seasons. It represents resourcefulness and the deep knowledge of local, edible plants. It's a free and highly nutritious addition to the diet.

ingredients.name: Fresh Pigweed (Bbuga) Leaves
ingredients.notes: Young, tender leaves and shoots are best. Thoroughly washed to remove soil and debris.

steps.instruction: Thoroughly wash the bbuga leaves in several changes of water to remove all dirt, sand, and any small insects. Drain well in a colander.
Roughly chop the cleaned leaves if they are large.
Heat the vegetable oil in a large skillet or pot over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until soft and translucent, about 3-4 minutes.
If using, add the chopped tomato and cook for 2-3 minutes until it begins to soften.
Add the washed bbuga leaves to the pot. They will wilt down quickly.
Add the salt and 2 tablespoons of water. Stir everything together to combine.
Cover the pot and let it cook for 3-5 minutes over medium heat, until the leaves are completely wilted and tender.

cooking_indicators.visual: Leaves will turn a darker green and become soft.

steps.instruction: Remove the lid and stir. If there is excess liquid, let it cook uncovered for another minute to evaporate.
Taste and adjust seasoning if necessary. Serve immediately.
Serve the bbuga hot as a side dish.

serving_suggestions: Serve as a side dish with the main staple like Posho (Ugali), Matoke, or Rice. It pairs perfectly with any stew, such as bean stew, groundnut sauce, or meat dishes.
